Fig. 1 Experimental setup for generating the sandwich honeycomb plasma. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Power generation for various catalysts (total gas flow rate: 20 L/min; RH: 90 %). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XRD powder patterns of the bare monolith, ZSM-5/monolith, Co/ZSM-5/monolith, and Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Photographic images of the catalyst: (a) top view and (b) side view. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) Photographic images of the post-reaction catalyst, (b) SEM image of post-reaction catalyst, (c) distribution of Co on the surface of the post-reaction catalyst and (d) distribution of Pd on the surface of the post-reaction catalyst. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Catalytic activity at various SEI values using W/O monolith, bare monolith, ZSM-5/monolith, Co/ZSM-5/monolith and Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith catalysts under similar conditions (total gas flow rate: 20 L/min; C2H4: 20 ppm; RH: 90 %; SEI: 0–80 J/L). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Comparison of actual with predicted results along with normal probability plots for studentized residuals (a–b): ethylene conversion, (c–d): CO2 selectivity, and (e–f): energy efficiency. R2: 0.8985; Adeq pre: 26.13; Mean: 1.01; CV %: 2.79 Effect of metal on corona discharge plasma in a honeycomb catalyst and optimization of the critical parameters for ethylene removal Md. Mokter Hossain a b Young Sun Mok a ⁎ Sarah Wu b Van Toan Nguyen a Avik Denra a a Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Jeju National University, Jeju 63243, the Republic of Korea Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Jeju National University Jeju 63243 the Republic of Korea Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Jeju National University, Jeju 63243, Korea b Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of Idaho, 875 Perimeter Drive MS 0904, Moscow, ID 83844, United States Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of Idaho 875 Perimeter Drive MS 0904 Moscow ID 83844 United States Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of Idaho, 875 Perimeter Drive MS 0904, Moscow, ID, 83844, United States ⁎ Corresponding author. This work focused on the factors affecting the effective generation of corona discharge plasma in a honeycomb catalyst reactor. Pd, Co, and Ag were used as the active metal catalysts to investigate the plasma formation and decomposition of ethylene. Unlike the Ag-coated honeycomb catalyst, which resulted in excessive arcing, the Co-coated honeycomb monolith was able to generate stable plasma, but the discharge power was insufficient to decompose ethylene at an acceptable level. The incorporation of a small amount of Pd with Co significantly enhanced the discharge power and the ethylene removal performance. The catalytic activity of the prepared catalyst for the removal of ethylene was evaluated using plasma catalytic oxidation and thermal catalytic oxidation. ANOVA was used to assess the effect of single process factors and their relationships in the plasma process. All the process factors such as specific energy input (SEI), ethylene concentration, and flow rate were found to affect the ethylene conversion, CO2 selectivity, and energy efficiency (EE). Under the optimal conditions, i.e., an SEI of 80 J/L, an ethylene concentration of 20 ppm, and a flow rate of 20 L/min, the ethylene conversion was 85 %, CO2 selectivity was 70 %, and EE was 0.86 g/kW h. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Honeycomb catalyst Non-thermal plasma Ethylene Honeycomb plasma Conversion Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene (C2H4) is a natural ripening hormone that can be found in plants. It has numerous effects on the growth, development, and storage life of many fruits and vegetables even at deficient concentrations such as parts per billion (ppb; nL/L) to parts per million (ppm; μL/L) [1–3]. Ethylene is also accountable for changes in the surface and color of certain agricultural products, depending on the sensitivity of these products to this gas. Besides crops, ethylene can originate from many other sources, including automotive emissions, smoke, fluorescent lights, and plastics. It is a hazardous volatile organic compound (VOC) responsible for photochemical smog, organic aerosols, and ground-level O3 contamination [4–7]. Several techniques can be used to remove ethylene, including combustion, photocatalysis, adsorption, non-thermal plasma (NTP) oxidation, thermal catalytic oxidation (TCO) [8,9]. Among these methods, NTP has been proved to be highly effective and energy-efficient. However, this system has a few shortcomings like low conversion efficiency, low CO2 selectivity, and the undesirable by-products formation, resulting in the system being impractical when NTP is used alone [10–13]. However, these opacities can be overcome by using NTP in conjunction with a catalyst, also known as plasma catalytic oxidation (PCO) [14]. In the presence of the catalyst, NTP can effectively improve the selectivity towards CO2, lower the operating cost, and decrease the formation of unwanted by-products, making this system feasible for practical application [15–18]. Various types of NTP reactor designs are available, and among them, dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) [19–24], corona discharge [12,13,25–31], and gliding arc discharge [32,33] are most commonly used. The gliding arc plasma needs more power compared to the DBD and corona plasma. Packed-bed DBD reactors are unable to accommodate a high flow rate because of the large pressure drop associated with these reactors. Thus, in practice, corona-discharge-plasma based honeycomb catalytic reactor is more realistic. The reason behind using honeycomb monoliths is to overcome many of the existing problems in direct applications. By depositing metal onto the bare honeycomb monolith, the monolith can easily turn into a honeycomb catalyst which can be used for catalytic conversion reaction. The application of monolith catalysts can enhance energy efficiency and considerable cost reductions. It also offers more benefits than powder and pellets catalysts, such as better mass transfer and reusability. In addition, compared to packed bed reactors, honeycomb catalytic reactors can easily be used for solving environmental issues as it has low-pressure drop, uniform distribution of gas flow and the capability of treating large volumes of gas. Numerous studies have already demonstrated the degradation of VOC from the exhaust gas and wastewater using corona plasma discharge [34–39]. However, the generation of stable corona discharge plasma in a honeycomb catalyst is challenging. This work focused on the generation of corona discharge plasma in a honeycomb catalyst and the optimization of process variables for the removal of ethylene. The effect of the metal on the corona discharge characteristics and the ethylene removal was investigated by varying the metal, namely palladium (Pd), cobalt (Co), and silver (Ag), ZSM-5 being used as the catalyst support. A Pd-coated monolith is known to sustain highly stable plasma that is suitable for practical use [14,28,31]. However, the price of Pd limits its use as a catalyst. Therefore, we attempted using more affordable alternatives such as Co and Ag to obtain stable corona discharge plasma. The performance of NTP is influenced by various parameters such as the flow rate, applied energy density, concentration of VOCs, and relative humidity (RH). Hence, optimizing the experimental conditions considering all these parameters remains a formidable challenge [40]. Most of the previous studies investigated the influence of individual process parameters on the VOC removal performance by the plasma catalysis process using experimental approaches [14,19,40,41]. Typically, this is a time-consuming process as a large number of experiments need to be conducted to determine the optimal parameters. In contrast, response surface methodology (RSM) has been widely used for optimizing the process variables [42,43]. RSM enables experiments to be designed to deliver adequate and reliable response measurements. On the basis thereof, a mathematical model is developed that best fits the data obtained from the experimental design, and enables the independent variables that either maximize or minimize the response to be optimized. RSM is a formidable tool for statistical modeling in that it requires fewer experimental runs according to the experimental design [44]. However, only a few studies have used the RSM method to optimize NTP parameters [45–47]. In this work, central composite design (CCD) was used to determine the correlation between the input process factors (such as the SEI, flow rate, and concentration) and output responses (conversion, selectivity towards CO2, and energy efficiency). 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials ZSM-5 (HSZ-822HOA, BET surface area = 330 m2/g), colloidal silica (Ludox HS-40, 40 wt% suspension in H2O), and honeycomb monolith (300 cells per square inch) were purchased from Tosoh Corp., Japan [12,48], Sigma Aldrich, Korea, and Ceracomb Co., Ltd., Korea, respectively. All the metal salts, namely, cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), silver (I) nitrate (AgNO3), and palladium (II) nitrate dihydrate (Pd(NO3)2·2H2O) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich, Korea, Daejung Chemicals & Metals Co., Ltd., Korea, and Kojima Chemicals Co., Ltd., Japan, respectively. Washcoating slurry was prepared with ZSM-5, colloidal silica, and deionized (DI) water at the ratio of ZSM-5: binder: water = 3:1:16. The catalyst support (ZSM-5) and the binder constituted 20 wt% of the solution and was thus referred to as the 20 % slurry. A glass beaker was used for preparing the solution using these materials. Finally, the solution was homogenized by stirring overnight in the beaker sealed with paper film to prevent water evaporation. 2.2 ZSM-5 coating procedure Two usual cordierite honeycomb monoliths with the dimension of 50 × 50 mm2 (height×diameter) were cut from commercial usual cordierite honeycomb monoliths using a diamond-coated cutter. After cutting the monoliths, they were washed by immersing them in an acetone-filled beaker with sonication for 40 min. The monoliths were put in an oven for 2 h at 150 °C soon after sonication for drying. The weights of the monoliths were measured and recorded once the monoliths were dried. After dryng, the monoliths were kept in a ziplock bag so that no contamination could happen. For having a coating layer on the monolith, dry monolith from ziplock was taken and then submerged in the slurry solution for 3 min. After that, the monolith was air-treated (10 L/min) to eliminate the extra slurry from the channels to avoid blocking and then put in over to dry. The temperature of the oven was increased to 90 °C from 24 °C at the rate of 1.5 °C/min, which required 44 min. The temperature was kept unchanged to 90 °C for 2 h. The oven’s temperature was further raised to 150 °C in 25 min and kept unchanged for 3 h. This process can be repeated several times based on the expected loading amount. Completion of the loading was followed by annealing treatment at 600 °C (time to reach 600 °C: 192 min (3 °C/min from room temperature (24 °C)) for 5 h. The purpose of the annealing treatment was to increase the robustness of the coating. The loading specifications of the monoliths are summarized in Table 1. 2.3 Preparation of the catalysts All the catalysts were prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method. The uniformity of the metal deposition on the monoliths can be increased by saturating them several times instead of only once. Several aqueous solutions of the metal salts (Co alone, Pd alone, Ag alone, and a mixture of Co and Pd) were prepared (the amount of metal depends on the weight of the ZSM-5) to deposit the metals on the monoliths. It was essential to determine the amount of DI water that was needed to saturate the bare monolith and 1 g of ZSM-5 powder. In this study, it was found that 15.0 and 0.8 mL of DI water were necessary to saturate the bare monolith (height of 5 cm and diameter of 5 cm (volume: 98.18 cm3)) and 1 g of ZSM-5 powder, respectively. Once the catalyst was saturated by the solution containing the metal salt, the catalyst was allowed to dry at ambient conditions for 2 h. After that, the catalyst was put in the oven. The temperature of the oven was set to 90 °C for 3 h and then increased to 150 °C and maintained this temperature for 2 h such that the catalyst could dry properly. Each time after saturation of the catalyst by the solution of metal salt, the monolith was put inside the oven, but before placing inside the oven, it was dried at room temperature for 2 h. The temperature of the oven was set to 90 °C and was taken 33 min at a rate of 2 °C/min to reach the setpoint from 24 °C. This set temperature was kept unchanged for 3 h. These steps were repeated three times for each catalyst. Finally, the impregnated monolith was calcinated for 5 h at 600 °C by raising the temperature at a rate of 4 °C/min from 24 °C, which took about 144 min to reach 600 °C. 2.4 Apparatus and methods The experimental setup composed of two perforated electrodes and one quartz cylinder is shown in Fig. 1. Both electrodes are manufactured from stainless steel. The thickness and the diameter of the electrodes were 2 mm and 50 mm, respectively. The electrode has 3 mm diameter holes all over the surface with a distance 3 mm from each other. The distance between the two electrodes was fixed at 52 mm. The powered electrode was placed 2 mm away from the monolith to give a space for plasma formation, and no gap was left between the ground electrode and monolith. A pump was used to feed ambient air, along with water vapor, into the reactor by controlling the flow meter (Dwyer Instruments, Inc., USA). The relative humidity (RH) of air was controlled by humidifying a part of the air and mixing this air with another part of dry air. Feed gas humidity was constantly monitored using a humidity meter (TES-1370 NDIR CO2 Temperature Humidity meter), while a thermocouple (ED6-FKMAP4, HANYOUNG NUX, South Korea) was used to monitor the gas temperature inside the reactor. 400 Hz AC power source was used to generate plasma. Tektronix (DPO 3034, Tektronix, USA) oscilloscope, a high-voltage probe (P6015A, Tektronix, USA), and a current transformer (Model 2100, Pearson Electronics, USA) were used to record all the electrical data. The outlet gas of the reactor was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) (Bruker 450-GC, USA), which was outfitted with a 60-m long capillary column (BR-624 ms, Bruker, USA). To determine the catalytic activity of the catalyst, an electric furnace (Daeheung Science Co., DTF-50300, Korea) was used. The characterization of the catalysts has been done using X-ray diffraction (XRD) (3rd Generation Empyrean, Malvern Panalytical, UK). The morphological structure of the surface of the catalysts was done using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), and the presence of the metals on the catalyst surface was confirmed using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) (Hitachi SU-70, Japan and HORIBA Scientific, Japan, respectively). The resistivity of the catalysts was determined by a digital LCR meter (Protek 9216B, Protek, Korea). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy was performed on FTIR-7600 (Lambda Scientific, Australia). To determine the discharge power (P), resistivity (ρ), conductivity (σ), ethylene conversion (RE) or ethylene oxidation, and the CO2 ( S CO 2 ) selectivity, the following equations were used: (1) P W = 1 T ∫ 0 T V t I ( t ) dt The resistivity was calculated using the following equation (2) ρ Ω m = RA L where R is the resistance, A is the area of the disk, and L is the length/thickness of the disk. Conductivity is the inverse of resistivity. Here, it is given by (3) σ S / m = 1 ρ The energy density/specific energy input (SEI) was calculated using the following equation (4) SEI J / L = P ( W ) × 60 Q ( L / min ) where 60 is used as a time unit conversion factor from min to s. (5) RE % = [ ethylene ] inlet − [ ethylene ] outlet [ ethylene ] inlet × 100 % (6) S CO 2 % = [ CO 2 ] outlet 2 × ( [ ethylene ] inlet − ethylene outlet ) × 100 % The energy efficiency (EE) was determined by the following equation (7) EE % = [ C 2 H 4 ] inlet × M C 2 H 4 × RE C 2 H 4 × 3.6 × 10 6 SEI × V m × 100 % here [ C 2 H 4 ] inlet , M C 2 H 4 , RE C 2 H 4 , SEI, and V m represent the inlet concentration, molar weight of ethylene (g/mol), conversion (%), energy density (J/L), and molar volume of the gas (L), respectively. The factor 3.6 × 10 6 is used to obtain the EE in g/kW h. 2.5 Experimental design Design Expert Software (DES) (version 12.0) with three factors and three levels were used for the purpose of statistical design for the experiments and data analysis. The CCD and RSM were applied to explore the influence of each process factor and the interrelations among the different factors on the NTP reaction activity for the degradation of ethylene. The CCD is the most popular class of design used for fitting the second-order models. Three input variables were studied, including the specific energy input (SEI) ( X 1 ), ethylene concentration ( X 2 ), and total flow rate ( X 3 ), while the responses were the ethylene conversion ( Y 1 ), CO2 selectivity ( Y 2 ) and energy efficiency ( Y 3 ). The range and levels used in this experiment (coded and uncoded) are listed in Table 2. Based on Table 2, a total of 30 experiments were conducted to determine the surface responses, including 10 center points and 20 non-center points, provided in Table 3. The following equation expresses the relationship between the coded and real values: (8) x i = X i − X 0 ∆ X i where x i and X i represent the coded value of the i th independent variable and real value of the independent variable, respectively. X 0 and ∆ X i represent the center point and step change of X i . To optimize the SEI, ethylene concentration, and total flow rate, a quadratic polynomial equation was developed to predict the response as a function of the independent variables. Their interrelationships are given below: (9) Y = β 0 + ∑ i = 1 k β i x i + ∑ i = 1 k β ii x i 2 + ∑ i = 1 k − 1 ∑ j = 2 k β ij x i x j + … … … + ε where Y , k , and ε represent the predicted response, number of variables, and residual value, respectively, whereas x i and x j (i = 1→3; j = 1→3; i ‡ j) represent the independent variables in the form of coded values; β 0 , β i , β ii , and β ij are constant regression coefficients of the model [45,49,50]. An analysis of ANOVA with F-test has been used to investigate the pragmatic relationships between the factors and NTP reaction activity. As it is a mathematical model, the quality and precision of the model was evaluated by the coefficient of determination (R2), adjusted R2 (Adj. R2), predicted R2 (Pre. R2), adequate precision (Adeq pre), and lack of fit. Adequate precision was used to determine the signal-to-noise ratio of the regression models. Typically, a ratio greater than 4 is desirable [51]. The coefficient of variance (CV) is the ratio of the standard error for estimating the mean value of the observed response that defines the reproducibility of the model. The CV value should not exceed 10 % to ensure reproducibility [52]. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Plasma formation with various metals and their mixtures This experiment aims to determine the optimal metal loading capable of generating strong plasma to decompose VOCs. The previous study [31] found that the palladium-coated monolith could generate strong plasma to remove the VOCs from the diluted air. However, the energy efficiency seemed to be insufficient compared to other systems [31]. To improve the energy efficiency, the metal loading should be increased such that the catalytic activity can be improved. This presents a problem in that the palladium loading cannot exceed 5 wt% based on the support materials [12], because, beyond 5 wt%, the honeycomb catalyst causes severe arcing. At 6 wt% the Pd-coated monolith gave rise to intense arcing, which can be seen in Figs. S1(a) and S1(b). The Ag-coated catalyst with less than 6 wt% Ag generated poor plasma, and more than 6 wt% caused excessive arcing, making this catalyst impractical to use for this corona configuration. The arcing surface of the Ag-coated catalyst was captured photographically and is presented in Fig. S1(c) and S1(d). The blackish color on the surfaces of the catalysts was formed as a result of the arcing effect of the AC current. On the other hand, cobalt also has excellent catalytic activity and the loading can be increased to 10 wt% based on the Supporting materials. When the cobalt loading surpassed 10 wt%, arcing was also observed to start occurring, which limited the metal loading; as a result, cobalt alone generated insufficient power. Fig. 2 shows the discharge power obtained by the bare monolith, ZSM-5/monolith, Pd 5 wt%/ZSM-5/monolith, Ag 6 wt%/ZSM-5/monolith, Co, and also by Co to which a percentage of Pd had been added. The output power results before arcing with Pd alone and Ag alone were also added for the sake of comparison. Bare monolith and ZSM-5/monolith generated very poor power compared to metal-coated monoliths. Pd 5 wt%/ZSM-5/monolith generated 32 W, which was the highest compared to other catalysts. On the other hand, only 12 W of output power was obtained with Ag 6 wt%/ZSM-5/monolith. The figure does not present any data using Pd alone and Ag alone with 10 wt%, because the 10 wt% Pd-coated monolith and Ag-coated monolith give rise to arcing. This experiment indicated that a mixture of Co and Pd with the ratio between 8 wt% and 2 wt% (Co:Pd = 4:1), respectively, yielded the highest discharge power compared to other ratios and was considered to be the optimal ratio between Co and Pd for this experiment. 3.2 Measurement of resistivity and conductivity by varying the metal content The resistivity was measured to determine the effect of the metal content on the conductivity. As conductivity is the inverse of resistivity, the resistivity was calculated using powder catalysts. The powder catalysts were prepared using the same process that was used to prepare the monolith catalysts. A mixture of Co and Pd was found to draw maximum discharge power without arcing. Powder catalyst (2 g) was used to fabricate the disk by applying 15 MPa pressure for 30 s. The prepared disk had a diameter of 13 mm. The thickness of the disk was 0.9 mm, which was considered as length (see Eq. (2)) to calculate the resistivity. This study aimed to establish the impact of metal loading on resistivity. As a result, 2, 5, 7, and 10 wt% metal was loaded to verify the extent to which the resistivity changed. Two different types of catalysts were prepared for each data point: Co-coated catalysts and a mixture of Co and Pd-coated catalysts. The ratio of the Co to the Pd coated catalysts (Co-Pd/ZSM-5) was constant at Co:Pd = 4:1. Fig. 3 shows the dependency of the resistivity and conductivity on the metal contents. With similar metal content, the resistivity with the catalyst coating consisting of Co alone was slightly higher compared to that of the Co and Pd mixture, which indicated that the resistivity of the Pd catalyst is lower than that of the Co. This trend was similar for every set of catalysts. Therefore, increasing the metal loading decreases the resistivity, resulting in an increase the conductivity. For comparison purposes, 10 wt% Ag-coated catalyst (Ag/ZSM-5) and 10 wt% Pd-coated catalyst (Pd/ZSM-5) are also shown in the figure. The 10 wt% Ag-coated catalyst was 1.6 times (Fig. 3(b)) and the 10 wt% Pd-coated catalyst was 1.8 times (Fig. 3(b)) more conductive than the 10 wt% Co-coated catalysts, respectively. This could be one of the main reasons the Co loading can be as high as 10 wt% to generate honeycomb corona plasma without arcing. All the catalysts were loaded in the monolith based on the support materials ZSM-5. 6 g of ZSM-5 was loaded to both the catalysts (Co 10 wt%/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst and (Pd 8 wt% & Co 2 wt%)/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst). Based on loading ZSM-5, 10 % metal (0.6 g) was loaded on the monoliths. To get 0.6 g of Co in Co 10 wt%/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst, a liquid solution was made using 3.02 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (10%) (considering ASSAY: 98 %), and then all the solution was transferred to the monolith. In the same way, for (Pd 8 wt% & Co 2 wt%)/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst, a liquid solution was made using 2.42 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (8 %) and 0.30 g Pd(NO3)2·2H2O (2 %), and then the solution was transferred to the monolith. 3.3 Characterization of the catalysts The bare monolith, ZSM-5/monolith, Co/ZSM-5/monolith, and Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith were characterized using XRD to examine the crystallinity and typical peak patterns. All these coated monoliths, including the bare ones, were crystalline by nature and the different XRD peak intensities can be seen in Fig. 4. The XRD results seem to be matched with the characteristic diffraction pattern of the cordierite phase ( ICDD file no. 00-012-0303) [12,14,53]. The coated monoliths have higher peak intensities than the bare ones, which indicate the increase in crystallinity in the presence of the ZSM-5 coating. The metals’ presence on the monolith is well known to lower the crystallinity, which mostly depends on the loaded amount of metals. On the other hand, the metals’ presence on the monolith slightly decreased the crystallinity compared to that of the ZSM-5 coated monolith. The diffraction peak at 2θ = 42.40° confirmed the presence of the metal oxide (CoO) for Co/ZSM-5/monolith and Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith (JCPDS File no. 14-0133) [12]. No peak related to Pd was observed, indicating the low concentration of Pd. Typical FE-SEM micrographs of the Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith honeycomb are shown in Fig. 5. As for all the catalysts, ZSM-5 was used to support the catalyst using similar conditions; therefore, the surface morphology of each catalyst remained the same. On the other hand, the addition of catalysts does not change the surface morphology. As a result, the catalyst images, SEM images, and EDS elemental mapping images are presented of only the Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst. Fig. 5(a) and 6(b) show the photographic images of the catalyst-coated honeycomb monolith. A rice-like shape having the size of 1.68 µm in length and 0.47 µm in width of particle has been formed on the honeycomb channels using ZSM-5 coating, and therefore metal oxide formed on those particles (Fig. 5(c)). The coating thickness was also examined using SEM and was found to be approximately 69 µm presented in Fig. 5(d). Fig. 5(e) and 5(f) show that the Co and Pd that are well scattered over the surface of the monolith act as active sites of catalyst to remove VOC, which was accomplished by the EDS. Fig. 6 shows FE-SEM micrographs of post-reaction of the Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst. Fig. 6(a) shows that the physical appearance of the catalysts did not change even after the catalytic reaction. From the SEM image (Fig. 6(b)), it is clearly seen that the surface morphology of the catalyst also remains unchanged after reactions indicating the high durability of the catalyst. On the other hand, EDS elemental mapping images (Fig. 6(c) and 6(d)) show that the Co and Pd metal still remain on the surface. It seems that Pd content might have decreased a little, which is obvious because when plasma bombardment happened on the catalyst surfaces, some of the metal may be blown out from the catalyst surfaces, which can be seen in Fig. 6(d) inside the white circle. This is also true for Co, but the Co has a higher content than Pd; therefore, EDS images still remain similar to fresh catalysts. The post-reaction SEM and EDS elemental mapping images confirmed that the surface morphology and the metal oxide remain almost unchanged, indicating the long-lasting durability of the catalyst. 3.4 Catalytic activity with the prepared catalysts under similar conditions The PCO and TCO performance between the Co/ZSM-5/monolith and Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith catalysts was assessed under similar conditions to choose the best catalyst for the next step of the study. Bimetallic catalysts are well known to be more effective than monometallic catalysts [54–56]. Bimetallic catalysts expose the properties of both metals during the catalytic activity and generate characteristic properties, which helps to have strong synergetic effects between the two metals present. The bimetallic particles’ formation can be arbitrarily orientated, such as alloy or intermetallic, cluster-in-cluster or core-shell structures, etc. [57]. Researchers are actively working to determine the relationship between the electronic configuration of the metal and the behaviors of catalysts, which is eventually resulted in the bimetallic catalyst becoming one of the leading groups of heterogeneous catalysts [57–62]. The main advantage of the bimetallic catalysts is the synergic effect, but the properties are also dependent on the type of catalyst and reactions. It is important to note that not all bimetallic catalysts present a synergistic effect. Fig. 7 shows the ethylene conversion using bare monolith, without monolith, ZSM-5/monolith, Co/ZSM-5/monolith, and Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith. For this study, gas flow rate, ethylene concentration, and RH remain constant at 20 L/min, 20 ppm, and 90 %. Without monolith in the reactor, there was no plasma and, therefore, no conversion. With bare and ZSM-5/monolith, the energy density was so poor that the ethylene conversion was reaming just 2–5 % at an energy density of 9–20 J/L. On the other hand, no catalytic activities were also observed with metal-coated catalysts when the energy density was less than 30 J/L. When the energy density increases from 30 to 40 J/L, the conversion of ethylene rapidly increases, indicating the catalytic activities of the catalysts. This rapid increase of conversion happened due to catalytic activity as well as increasing of energetic electrons and reactive species in the reactor. With Co/ZSM-5/monolith, a maximum of 50 J/L energy density was obtained. Around 50 % of ethylene conversion was obtained at this condition, and at the same condition with Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith, around 56 % of ethylene conversion was observed. In comparison, it is clearly shown that adding Pd to the Co improved the plasma catalytic activity over that of the Co catalyst alone, which supports the results of previous studies. The evolution of the ethylene oxidation as a function of the temperature for both catalysts was also studied using TCO, as shown in Fig. S2. With the Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst, the oxidation of ethylene began at a temperature of 180 °C, whereas no ethylene oxidation was observed at the same temperature using the Co/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst. The first sign of ethylene oxidation using the Co/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst was at 200 °C and at this condition, 7 % conversion was achieved with the Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst. As shown in Fig. S2, 100 % conversion was achieved at 420 and 460 °C using the Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith and Co/ZSM-5/monolith catalysts, respectively. The TCO results suggested that the prepared Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst offers higher catalytic activity than that of Co/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst. This experiment also clearly indicates that adding a small percentage of Pd enhanced the catalytic activity. Therefore, all the upcoming experiments were conducted using only the Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst. 3.5 Fitting of process models and statistical analysis The RSM is most often used to build models for making predictions. Therefore, the prediction variance (ANOVA) is important for evaluating and comparing designs. The experimental data of the CCD design based on the RSM method are provided in Table 3. Three independent factors, three coded variables, and three levels were used (Table 2) to specify the relationship between the conversion, selectivity for CO2, energy efficiency, and input parameters. All the coefficients of the polynomial equations were determined from the experimental data using CCD to assess and predict the values of the response variable. The experimental data, including the conversion, selectivity for CO2, and energy efficiency, along with the respective predicted data, are also presented in Table 3. The predicted data are in good agreement with the experimental data. The quadratic models for each response were established to exhibit the input factors, and the output NTP activities are given by Eqs. (5)–(7). (10) Y 1 = 61.6900 + 9.0800 x 1 − 13.0800 x 2 + 1.5000 x 3 + 0.5000 x 1 x 2 + 0.5001 x 1 x 3 + 0.0001 x 2 x 3 + 1.81 x 1 2 − 0.6912 x 2 2 − 8.9400 x 3 2 (11) Y 2 = 55.2500 + 8.5000 x 1 − 11.6700 x 2 + 0.8333 x 3 + 3.5000 x 1 x 2 + 0.0013 x 1 x 3 − 0.5003 x 2 x 3 + 0.1765 x 1 2 − 0.8235 x 2 2 − 6.8200 x 3 2 (12) Y 3 = 1.0900 + 0.0265 x 1 + 0.0944 x 2 + 0.0261 x 3 + 0.0516 x 1 x 2 + 0.0043 x 1 x 3 + 0.0077 x 2 x 3 + 0.0325 x 1 2 − 0.0938 x 2 2 − 0.1587 x 3 2 Where Y 1 , Y 2 , and Y 3 represent the conversion, selectivity for CO2, and energy efficiency, respectively. The ANOVA was performed to evaluate the acceptability and impact of the regression model. The ANOVA results for Eqs. (10)–(12) are summarized in Table 4. The significance of each coefficient was determined by the F- and P-values. Normally, a smaller P-value and larger F-value indicate the significance of the respective response [45,50,63,64]. The regression for the conversion, selectivity for CO2, and energy efficiency were found to be statistically significant because all the P-values (conversion: < 0.0001; CO2 selectivity: < 0.0001; energy efficiency: < 0.0001) were smaller along with a larger F-value (conversion: 357.84; CO2 selectivity: 33.83; energy efficiency: 62.79), as in Table 4. The fit of the models was justified by the coefficient of determination (R2). The conversion (Y1), selectivity for CO2 (Y2), and energy efficiency (Y3) of the PCO of ethylene were found to be 0.9879, 0.9716, and 0.9658, respectively, which indicates that at least 98.79 %, 97.16 %, and 96.58 % of the response values can be assigned to the identified independent variables. Generally, the R2 value is expected to be as close as possible to 1 to ensure a closer and more reliable model fit for the surface response. As in Table 4, all the R2 values are very close to 1, which confirms the validation of the models. The adjusted R2 was also found to be high or close to 1 (Y1: 0.9806; Y2: 0.9534; Y3: 0.9504) for each response suggesting the high accuracy of the model along with experimental data. The predicted coefficient of determination R2 for all the cases was also high (Y1: 0.9816; Y2: 0.9235; Y3: 0.8985), indicating the high significance of the model fit. Only 1.84 % for the conversion, 7.65 % for the CO2 selectivity, and 10.15 % for the energy efficiency could not be explained by the model of the total variations. All these predicted R2 values are in good agreement with all the respective adjusted R2 values. The adequate precisions were 77.51, 23.44, and 26.13, which were much higher than that of the critical value 4 for the ethylene conversion, CO2 selectivity, and energy efficiency, respectively, indicating a satisfactory signal-to-noise ratio for the model. On the other hand, the CV, which is the ratio of the standard error, was found to be 1.81 % for Y1, 5.98 % for Y2, and 2.79 % for Y3. Therefore, these CV values are much smaller than the critical value of 10 %, implying the reproducibility, along with good precision and reliability, of the experiments. Fig. 8(a, c, e) shows a diagnostic plot of the predicted versus the actual values of the conversion, CO2 selectivity, and energy efficiency that help us determine the model adequacy. The actual values were taken from the experimental data using 30 runs, and the predicted values were calculated using Eqs. (10)–(12). The figures clearly show that the distribution of all the values (experimental and predicted) closely approximates a linear distribution, suggesting the model equations are well fitted with the response. The regression models have been presented with their coded and actual factors to confirm that the selected models adequately approximate the actual system. Fig. 8(b, d, f) shows the normal probability plots for the studentized residuals for the ethylene conversion, CO2 selectivity, and energy efficiency. These normal probability plots predict whether the residuals follow a normal distribution. From Fig. 8(b, d, f), the distribution seemed to be approximately linear, indicating the normal distribution of experimental and predicted values. Nevertheless, some dispersion is likely even with a normal distribution. Therefore, the data presented in Fig. 8(b, d, f) can be evaluated to be normally distributed in terms of the responses of particular models. 3.6 Influence of the independent variables on the surface responses The influence of independent variables such as the SEI, gas flow rate, and ethylene concentration on the surface responses was studied for the ethylene conversion, CO2 selectivity, and energy efficiency. All these independent variables are listed in Table 3. The response surfaces based on a quadratic equation regression model open a new window to assess the significance of individual input parameters and their interactions on the NTP catalytic treatment of ethylene in terms of the conversion, CO2 selectivity, and energy efficiency. 3.6.1 Influence of SEI and ethylene concentration The hybrid influence of the SEI and ethylene concentration on the conversion and CO2 selectivity is shown in Fig. 9(a–b). Under this condition, the flow rate and RH were kept constant at 20 L/min and 90 %, respectively. As the energy density increased from 60 to 80 J/L, both the ethylene conversion and CO2 selectivity increased (see Fig. 9(a–b)). This occurred because, with the higher energy density, the catalytic activity of the catalyst was increased along with the number of active species (such as ions, free radicals, energetic electrons, excited atoms, etc.) and reactive species (free radicals and reactive oxygen species) in the plasma zone [28,65,66]. These increased plasma species, along with the increased catalytic activity of the catalyst, promoted increased oxidation and selectivity for CO2. On the other hand, both the conversion and selectivity for CO2 decreased when the ethylene concentration increased from 20 to 40 ppm. The reason behind this, in particular the energy density, is that the amount of active and reactive species remain almost similar. As a result, the available plasma species decrease per ppm of ethylene with increasing input concentration, resulting in a decrease in the conversion and selectivity for CO2. In addition, a higher ethylene concentration of the feed gas may act as a poison that can reduce the interaction between air and energetic electrons, leading to a decrease in the formation of reactive species [67]. The maximum ethylene conversion and CO2 selectivity were recorded at approximately 85 % and 70 % when the energy density and ethylene concentration were set at 80 J/L and 20 ppm, respectively. Fig. 9(c–d) shows the hybrid effect of SEI and gas flow rate on the conversion and CO2 selectivity. Under these conditions, the ethylene concentration and RH were kept constant at 20 ppm and 90 %, respectively. A similar phenomenon (influence of SEI and ethylene concentration) can be seen in the case of the SEI: the increase in the SEI from 60 to 80 J/L resulted in an increase in both the conversion and CO2 selectivity. Therefore, the influence of the SEI is not discussed any further in this section. Increasing the flow rate from 15 to 25 L/min (Fig. 9(a–b)) clearly demonstrates the increasing and decreasing trend for both the conversion and CO2 selectivity. At a flow rate of 15 L/min, the plasma inside the honeycomb catalyst was not perfectly uniform, resulting in lesser decomposition (see Fig. S3(a)). At a flow rate of 15 L/min, it seems plasma was not formed through all the channels or partially formed. An increase in the flow rate from 15 to 20 L/min allowed all the channels to form plasma uniformly (Fig. S3(b)) which brought maximum conversion and CO2 selectivity. This actually happened due to the formation of uniform plasma at 20 L/min, resulting in the maximum conversion. A flow rate higher than 20 L/min also forms uniform plasma inside the honeycomb catalyst, but both the conversion and CO2 selectivity were lower. Generally, a higher gas flow rate hampers the reaction performance for the following two reasons [46]: (i) a higher gas flow rate introduces more ethylene molecules in the reactor zone per unit time, which reduces the generation of active species, thereby resulting in the lower conversion and CO2 selectivity, and (ii) a higher gas flow rate means higher GHSV, which indicates a shorter reaction time for the gas compounds in the plasma discharge zone. As the gas flow rate increases, the residence time for collisions between the ethylene molecules and active species becomes shorter. As a result, the intermediates and ethylene did not react appropriately due to insufficient time and leaving the plasma zone, causing the conversion and CO2 selectivity to deteriorate. Fig. 9(e–f) expresses the effect of the gas flow rate and ethylene concentration on the NTP oxidation of ethylene at constant energy density. The energy density and RH were kept constant at 80 J/L and 90 %, respectively, for this study. The effect of the gas flow rate and ethylene concentration on the conversion and CO2 selectivity was discussed in previous sections. Therefore, in this experiment we tried to understand the behavior of the conversion and CO2 selectivity at constant energy density. However, the conversion and selectivity phenomenon are almost similar to those in Fig. 9(a–b) and Fig. 9(c–d). Therefore Fig. 9(e–f) clearly shows that, as the ethylene concentration increases from 20 to 40 ppm, the conversion (Fig. 9(e)) decreases from 85 % to 50 %, and the CO2 selectivity (Fig. 9(f)) decreases from 70 % to 45 % for constant energy density at 80 J/L. 3.6.2 Energy efficiency Fig. 10 shows the energy efficiency at various energy densities, gas flow rates, and ethylene concentrations. All the experiments were carried out at constant RH of 90 %. Fig. 10(a) shows the energy efficiency when the ethylene concentration was kept constant at 20 ppm. As the energy density increased from 60 to 80 J/L, the energy efficiency seemed to decrease slightly, indicating that the effect of the SEI on the energy efficiency was smaller when the ethylene concentration was constant. The conversion could explain this result as it is proportionally related with the energy efficiency. Ethylene conversion can be seen in Fig. S4 as a function of the SEI, which increases from 30 to 80 J/L in intervals of 10 J/L. Drawing a right triangle starting with the two data points enables the hypotenuse to be calculated, which can determine the slope. Therefore, a larger slope could be considered to suggest higher energy efficiency. Fig. S4 clearly shows that the base remains constant for all the cases as the interval value is unchanged. The only changing parameter is the height; therefore, the hypotenuse can be considered to be a function of the height. When the SEI increased from 30 to 80 J/L, the height (the value of the base and height were taken from the origin software using the dimensions option) was decreasing, indicating that the slope was decreasing, and therefore, that the energy efficiency was decreasing. The effect of the flow on the energy efficiency can be explained by the results in Section 3.6.1. As the energy efficiency is directly proportional to the conversion and inversely proportional to the SEI, the energy efficiency follows the same trend as in Section 3.6.1. The maximum conversion was obtained at a flow rate of 20 L/min because under this condition, the maximum conversion was achieved (Section 3.6.1); therefore, the maximum energy efficiency was 0.88 g/kW h when the SEI was 60 J/L. Fig. 10(b) reveals the hybrid influence of the flow rate and ethylene concentration on the energy efficiency at constant energy density of 80 J/L. As the applied energy density is constant, the energy efficiency mainly depends on the input concentration and conversion of ethylene. Clearly, the increase in the ethylene concentration from 20 to 40 ppm leads to an increase in the energy efficiency from 0.74 to 1.22 g/kW h at a flow rate of 20 L/min. This result can be described using Eq. (7), according to which the input concentration and conversion have a proportional relationship with the energy efficiency. A sharp increase in the input concentration of the reactor does not result in a sharp decrease in the conversion (see Fig. S5); therefore, the energy efficiency mainly depends on the input concentration. As a result, the higher the input concentration, the higher the energy efficiency becomes in this study. An increase in the flow rate from 15 to 20 L/min increases the energy efficiency, and again a subsequent increase in the flow rate from 20 to 25 L/min decreases the energy efficiency. This phenomenon is attributable to the effect of the conversion, as discussed in Section 3.6.1. 3.7 FTIR analysis The decomposition of the ethylene was mainly through oxidation processes. In general, ethylene oxidizes and eventually forms CO2, and H2O in the presence of oxygen. As air has almost 21 % oxygen therefore CO2 and H2O formation are obvious as final products in the PCO process. The formation of CO2, H2O, and other by-products during the PCO and plasma oxidation were analyzed using FTIR. As the corona configuration could not be used to generate gas-phase plasma, therefore bare monolith was used to generate plasma for the plasma oxidation process. The basic conditions, such as ethylene concentration, the gas flow rate, and humidity were set at 500 ppm, 20 L/min, and 90 %, respectively, for taking FTIR. The PCO was conducted with an SEI of 60 and 80 J/L, whereas when bare monolith was used, the maximum energy density was obtained at around 12 J/L. The major gaseous products from the PCO of organic compounds were CO2, CO, and H2O. However, the generation of organic by-products was inevitable. Therefore, ketone, aldehyde, and alkane were also observed in PCO of ethylene. The peak intensities of CO2 ( Fig. 11) are well correlated to the SEI value; therefore, the peak intensities of CO2 become higher with increasing SEI. Compared with the case of plasma oxidation with the bare monolith in the reactor, no by-products were observed, and no signs of ethylene degradation. It was mainly due to the poor energy density (12 J/L) supplied to the reactor. 4 Conclusions This study focused on the generation of honeycomb plasma by transforming a bare honeycomb into a honeycomb catalyst by coating the honeycomb with a metal-containing catalyst. Co coated catalyst could not generate enough power to decompose ethylene at an acceptable level. Therefore, a small percentage of Pd was incorporated with Co to enhance the power and ethylene conversion. Compared with plasma formation, a stable discharge power of 27 W was obtained using the Co-Pd/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst for RH and a total flow rate of 90 % and 20 L/min, respectively. The Co/ZSM-5/monolith catalyst achieved a maximum of 18 W under similar conditions, therefore, only 50 % ethylene conversion was achieved. But when Pd was incorporated, the energy density was increased, as a result, the ethylene conversion was increased to 85 %. The SEM, EDS and XRD results revealed the well disperse of the metal oxides over the surface of the monolith, which increased the catalytic activity of the catalyst. The effects of the process factors (SEI, concentration, and flow) were studied to determine the extent to which they affected the decomposing the ethylene. The ANOVA results confirmed the importance of the models designed to regenerate the output responses. The most influential process factor was the SEI, on which the conversion, CO2 selectivity, and energy efficiency mostly depended. The other two process factors also played an important role in the conversion, CO2 selectivity, and energy efficiency. The major gaseous reaction products of the PCO were identified using an FT-IR spectrometer. By-products such as ketone, aldehyde, and alkane were detected together with the final products of CO, CO2, and H2O. As the prepared catalyst and reactor configuration successfully removed 85 % of the ethylene from the gas phase, this system could be used successfully to remove ethylene from the air. coredata.dc:description: This work focused on the factors affecting the effective generation of corona discharge plasma in a honeycomb catalyst reactor. Pd, Co, and Ag were used as the active metal catalysts to investigate the plasma formation and decomposition of ethylene. Unlike the Ag-coated honeycomb catalyst, which resulted in excessive arcing, the Co-coated honeycomb monolith was able to generate stable plasma, but the discharge power was insufficient to decompose ethylene at an acceptable level. The incorporation of a small amount of Pd with Co significantly enhanced the discharge power and the ethylene removal performance. The catalytic activity of the prepared catalyst for the removal of ethylene was evaluated using plasma catalytic oxidation and thermal catalytic oxidation. ANOVA was used to assess the effect of single process factors and their relationships in the plasma process. All the process factors such as specific energy input (SEI), ethylene concentration, and flow rate were found to affect the ethylene conversion, CO2 selectivity, and energy efficiency (EE). Under the optimal conditions, i.e., an SEI of 80 J/L, an ethylene concentration of 20 ppm, and a flow rate of 20 L/min, the ethylene conversion was 85 %, CO2 selectivity was 70 %, and EE was 0.86 g/kW h.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of metal on corona discharge plasma in a honeycomb catalyst and optimization of the critical parameters for ethylene removal
